index.title: Supakorn's Notebook
index.content:
Welcome to my little corner of the internet! I‚Äôm Supakorn or you can call me Gap and this is my digital garden where I put all the stuff I learn and think about.
Think of this like my public notebook. I write about things I‚Äôm working on, stuff I find interesting, and random thoughts that pop into my head. It‚Äôs not perfect, and sometimes my English might be a bit weird (I‚Äôm still learning!), but that‚Äôs okay - this is just me sharing what I know.
A little bit about me
I‚Äôm a student at sit,kmutt who loves tinkering with code and learning new things. I enjoy software development, cybersecurity (especially CTFs), and exploring different programming languages and frameworks.
This website is my way of learning in public - sharing what I discover along the way. If you found something useful here or want to chat, feel free to reach out on my X. I‚Äôd love to connect!
How this works
This site is built with Quartz and all my notes are connected. You can click on the links to jump between topics, or just browse around and see what catches your eye.


                  
                  Notes
                  
                


Everything here is a work in progress. I update things as I learn more, so don‚Äôt be surprised if you see changes. That‚Äôs just how gardens grow! üå±

blog/My-Thought-About-Using-AI.title: My Thought About Using AI
blog/My-Thought-About-Using-AI.content:
I‚Äôve been using AI since the first release of ChatGPT. I‚Äôve experimented with it in all kinds of ways ‚Äî from coding assistance to learning and research. And here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve learned after all this time:
AI is great. It really is. It can replace some parts of a developer‚Äôs work.
But if you use it without thinking, it will slowly replace your brain too.
I‚Äôm not against AI ‚Äî I actually use it a lot in my daily work.
But I refuse to let it think for me.
Here‚Äôs what I see many developers doing wrong:
They take a business requirement, copy it, and paste it straight into an AI prompt saying,

‚ÄúCreate this app for me.‚Äù

That‚Äôs the dumbest way to use AI.
If you do that, you‚Äôre not a developer ‚Äî you‚Äôre just a middleman between a requirement and a chatbot.
A real developer should:


Understand the problem first.


Summarize the business requirement.


Think and design a solution logically.


Write the core logic by themselves.


Then, after that, use AI for what it‚Äôs actually good at:


Creating a quick POC (proof of concept)


Doing research like ‚Äúhow to optimize this algorithm‚Äù


Or reviewing your existing code to catch mistakes


But if you let AI handle everything from the start, it will frame your thinking.
You‚Äôll get stuck inside the box that AI creates for you.
When something goes wrong ‚Äî say your code has bugs or doesn‚Äôt fit the business logic ‚Äî
you‚Äôll realize how hard it is to debug code that you didn‚Äôt truly write.
It‚Äôs like trying to fix someone else‚Äôs logic that you never understood.
And if the developer who‚Äôs assigned to that task doesn‚Äôt understand their own code,
how can anyone else understand it?
Sure, you could ask AI to explain it again:

‚ÄúHey AI, can you summarize what this code does?‚Äù

But let me ask you this ‚Äî
if AI lies or makes a wrong assumption,
how would you even know?
The best way to use AI is to let it handle the boring parts ‚Äî
like reading long documentation, summarizing repetitive content, or generating boilerplate code.
But the thinking ‚Äî that‚Äôs still your job.
Because once you stop thinking,
you‚Äôre no longer the developer.
You‚Äôre just the operator of someone else‚Äôs brain.

config/Customize-VScode-UI-Fonts.title: Customize VScode UI fonts
config/Customize-VScode-UI-Fonts.content:
Install Custom UI Style  Extension.
Open settings.json by press command + shift + p and search for settings.json.
Add this line to your settings.

  "custom-ui-style.font.sansSerif": "Jetbrains Mono",

There you go üéâ!

config/Make-Obsidian-Window-Translucent.title: Make Obsidian Window Translucent

config/Spicetify-theme-for-Spotify.title: Spicetify theme for Spotify
config/Spicetify-theme-for-Spotify.content:
Install Spicetify

# for linux/mac
curl -fsSL raw.githubusercontent.com/spicetify/cli/main/install.sh | sh
 
# for windows
iwr -useb raw.githubusercontent.com/spicetify/cli/main/install.ps1 | iex

Install Spicetify Marketplace

# for linux/mac
curl -fsSL raw.githubusercontent.com/spicetify/marketplace/main/resources/install.sh | sh
 
# for windows
iwr -useb raw.githubusercontent.com/spicetify/marketplace/main/resources/install.ps1 | iex

Set Spicetify theme to use Marketplace

spicetify config current_theme marketplace

Open spotify and Install theme üéâ

config/Tailscale-SSH-Setup.title: Tailscale SSH Setup
config/Tailscale-SSH-Setup.content:
Install tailscale

# mac
brew install tailsclae
 
# linux
curl -fsSL tailscale.com/install.sh | sh

Start tailscale

# linux
sudo tailscale up


Login On both Mac and Linux


SSH with Machine Address : login.tailscale.com/admin/machines

reader/Clean-Architecture-A-Craftsman's-.filePath: reader/Clean Architecture A Craftsman's Guide to Software Structure and Design by Robert C. Martin.md
reader/Clean-Architecture-A-Craftsman's-.title: Clean Architecture A Craftsman's Guide to Software Structure and Design by Robert C. Martin
reader/Clean-Architecture-A-Craftsman's-.content:
Chapter 1: What Is Design and Architecture?
Architecture vs Design: There is no difference between the two, not at all. It‚Äôs just a matter of perspective. Architecture focuses on high-level structure, while design focuses on low-level details. However, both must work together for optimal results.
The goal of software design is simple:

‚ÄúThe goal of software architecture is to minimize the human resources required to build and maintain the required system.‚Äù

Developers who say ‚Äúwe can clean it up later‚Äù are often overconfident, believing they‚Äôll have time to refactor in the future. But that time never comes because the work is never truly done, and there‚Äôs no capacity to go back and clean things up. This leads to a pile of messes that accumulate and overlap. The best approach is to do it right the first time.

‚ÄúThe only way to go fast, is to go well.‚Äù

When you prioritize software design, it benefits your work in many ways‚Äînot just your individual tasks, but the entire team‚Äôs workflow. Clean architecture makes collaboration easier, reduces costs, and from an executive perspective, it‚Äôs crucial to ensure your team‚Äôs work is maintainable and sustainable for the long term.
Chapter 2: A Tale of Two Values

reader/LongCat-Flash-Thinking-Technical-.title: LongCat-Flash-Thinking Technical Report
reader/LongCat-Flash-Thinking-Technical-.content:
Overview

560B parameter MoE model (only 27B active)
Open-source reasoning model from Meituan
Beats most open-source models on math, coding, formal proving

Training (2 Phases)
Phase 1: Cold-Start
Mid-training: Add STEM + coding data with curriculum learning to fix lack of reasoning patterns
SFT (3 specializations):

General Reasoning: STEM/code/logic problems with quality filtering
Formal Proving: Expert iteration to generate verified Lean4 proofs
Agentic: Dual-path selection to pick queries that NEED tools (64.5% token savings)

Phase 2: RL (Large-Scale)
DORA System: Asynchronous RL infrastructure

Split into Standalone Generators + Elastic Roles
Multiple policy versions, KV-cache reuse
Result: >3x speedup vs synchronous methods

Domain-Parallel Training:

Train separate STEM/Code/Agentic experts
Merge them into one model (prevents negative transfer)

Reward Models:

Non-verifiable: Discriminative model
STEM: Generative model with reasoning (98.8% accuracy vs 80.9% rule-based)

Key Results
Strong:

AIME-25: 90.6% (competitive with o3)
Formal proving: 67.6% vs DeepSeek 49.6% (+18%)
Coding: 79.4% (SOTA open-source)
Safety: Best overall

Weaker:

General knowledge (MMLU-Pro): 82.6%
Open-ended reasoning (Arena-Hard): 69.9%

Key Innovations

Domain-Parallel RL + Fusion: Train experts separately, merge into Pareto-optimal model
DORA System: >3x RL speedup via asynchronous streaming architecture
Dual-Path Tool Selection: Select only queries that benefit from tools
Generative Reward Models: GenRM with reasoning explanations (98.8% accuracy)

Resources

~20% of pre-training compute spent on RL
27B active / 560B total (MoE efficiency)

References

Paper: LongCat-Flash-Thinking Technical Report

dev/Compile-Protobuf-for-Go.title: Compile Protobuf for Go
dev/Compile-Protobuf-for-Go.content:
Install protoc-gen-go plugin for go

go install google.golang.org/protobuf/cmd/protoc-gen-go@latest

Compile your .proto file with Go and gRPC options

protoc --go_out=. --go_opt=paths=source_relative --go-grpc_out=. --go-grpc_opt=paths=source_relative path_to_protobuf_file

dev/Graceful-Shutdown-in-Go.title: Graceful Shutdown in Go
dev/Graceful-Shutdown-in-Go.content:
More info: victoriametrics.com/blog/go-graceful-shutdown
c := make(chan os.Signal, 1)
signal.Notify(c, os.Interrupt, syscall.SIGTERM)
 
go func() {
    <-c
    log.Println("Shutting down server...")
    _ = s.app.Shutdown(context.Background())
    log.Println("Server stopped")
}()

One of them is the lack of a live-server feature.
Here‚Äôs how I solved it:

bun recommended)

bun index.html

live-server

leetcode/leetcode---Two-Sum.title: Leetcode - Two Sum
leetcode/leetcode---Two-Sum.content:
Link - leetcode.com/problems/two-sum/description/
seen = {}
for i, num in enumerate(nums):
	need = target - num
	if need in seen:
		return [seen[need], i]
	seen[num] = i
Explains

Traverse the list only once.
For each element, compute need = target - num.
If need already exists in seen, then both required values for the answer are found.
Otherwise, store the current number in seen with its index.

Complexity

Time: O(n) - each element is processed once.
Space: O(n) - in the worst case, all elements are stored in seen.
